title: How the digital age has brought back expensive watches
text:
Bani McSpedden Watch Editor Oct 16, 2019 — 9.52am Share

I blame my parents for my watch addiction. They were resolutely uninterested in material things, instilling in me a reflex that unswervingly took the opposite direction. It might explain why my first watch came not from them, but from a family friend; I was 10, and the watch was an Oris.

It was reliably unreliable, thanks to being driven by a so-called pin-lever mechanism, an inferior movement Oris was saddled with by a 1930s Swiss law called the Watch Statute that froze upgrading the internals without government permission, something denied to Oris until 1966.

At least my rectangular 1950s model had cogs rather than a battery, not that you could see them through its slab of a back cover that was given over to the brand’s bravely regal shield.

I have no idea what happened to the watch, but Oris is still with us. One of the 10 top Swiss brands for a moment in the 1960s, it survived the ’70s and then settled into the value ranks, using movements from third-party manufacturers such as Sellita.

It's about $11,000, making it the most expensive Oris yet, but the Big Crown Pro-Pilot X Calibre still offers considerable value for money.

But things are on the upswing once more. The current range includes a slew of desirable dive models and handsome vintage editions. And, a few years back, an impressive in-house movement with 10-day power reserve made an appearance.

Now Oris has released a cleverly tweaked version of this Calibre 110 movement in a thoroughly contemporary version that raises the bar in every sense of the word.

The so-called Big Crown Pro-Pilot X is the brand’s most upmarket offering yet, with looks and price to match. Cased in titanium and mounted on a sleek titanium bracelet, the movement is not so much skeletonised – cut-away after the event – as designed from the outset to be the hero of the show, with everything revealed down to the coiled spring in the winding barrel.

It’s a visual treat, yet displays the time with unusual clarity, the galvanised industrial-finished surfaces of the movement forming a fascinating backdrop to highly luminescent hour, minute and seconds hands.
description: Three new models depart from their heritage and venture into new territory.
